identificationModule.briefTitle: The ACT Trial: Effects of Combined Aerobic Exercise and Cognitive Training in MCI
identificationModule.officialTitle: Efficacy and Mechanisms of Combined Aerobic Exercise and Cognitive Training (ACT) in MCI

descriptionModule.briefSummary: This multi-site clinical trial occurs at the University of Minnesota and University of Rochester. It tests the efficacy and additive/synergistic effects of an ACT intervention on cognition and relevant mechanisms (aerobic fitness, Alzheimer's disease \[AD\] signature cortical thickness, and default mode network \[DMN\]) in older adults with amnestic MCI (aMCI).
descriptionModule.detailedDescription: Because almost all drug trials for Alzheimer's disease (AD) have failed, developing non-pharmacological interventions with strong potential to prevent or delay the onset of AD in high-risk populations (e.g., those with mild cognitive impairment \[MCI\]) is critically important. Aerobic exercise and cognitive training are 2 promising interventions for preventing AD. Aerobic exercise increases aerobic fitness, which in turn improves brain structure and function, while cognitive training improves selective neural function intensively. Hence, combined Aerobic exercise and Cognitive Training (ACT) may very well have an additive or synergistic effect on cognition by complementary strengthening of different neural functions. Few studies have tested ACT's effects, and those studies have reported discrepant findings, largely due to varying ACT programs. The purpose of this single-blinded, 2×2 factorial Phase II randomized controlled trial (RCT) is to test the efficacy and additive/synergistic effects of a 6-month combined cycling and speed of processing (SOP) training intervention on cognition and relevant mechanisms (aerobic fitness, AD signature cortical thickness, and functional connectivity in the default mode network \[DMN\]) in older adults with amnestic MCI (aMCI).

keywords: cognitive impairment, Alzheimer's disease, exercise, cognitive training, imaging

armGroups.label: Cycling Only
armGroups.description: Moderate-intensity cycling, 3 times a week for 6 months, supervised by an exercise specialist

armGroups.label: Cognitive Training Only
armGroups.description: Computerized cognitive training, 3 times a week for 6 months, supervised by a specialist

armGroups.label: ACT
armGroups.description: Moderate-intensity cycling followed by computerized cognitive training, 3 times a week for 6 months, supervised by a specialist

armGroups.label: Stretching and Mental Stimulation Activities
armGroups.description: Stretching and mental stimulation activities, 3 times a week for 6 months, supervised by a specialist
interventionNames: Behavioral: Stretching and Mental Stimulating Activities

interventions.name: ACT
interventions.description: ACT stands for combined aerobic exercise and cognitive training.

interventions.name: Cycling Only
interventions.description: Cycling on a recumbent stationary cycle

interventions.name: Cognitive Training Only
interventions.description: Engage in cognitive training on a computer

interventions.name: Stretching and Mental Stimulating Activities
interventions.description: Stretching exercises and mental stimulating activities on a computer

primaryOutcomes.description: Change in the composite measures of executive function and episodic memory
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Change from baseline to 3, 6, 12, and 18 months

secondaryOutcomes.description: measured by the Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI)
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Change from baseline to 6, 12, and 18 months
Change from baseline to 6, 12, and 18 months

secondaryOutcomes.description: measured by the symptom-limited peak cycle-ergometer test
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Change from baseline to 3, 6, 12, and 18 months

secondaryOutcomes.description: Change in memory, global cognition, and instrumental activities of daily living will be assessed to make a clinical decision if a participant has progressed from MCI to AD
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Change in clinical status from MCI to AD at 6, 12, and 18 months

eligibilityModule.eligibilityCriteria:
Inclusion Criteria:

* A clinical diagnosis of MCI, Community-dwelling, Age 65 years and older, English-speaking, Adequate visual acuity, Verified exercise safety by medical provider, Stable on drugs affecting cognitive and psychological status, Verified MRI safety, and Capacity to consent.

Exclusion Criteria:

* Geriatric Depression Scale \< 5, Resting heart rate (HR) ≤50 due to arrhythmia or ≥100 beats/min, Neurological (e.g., dementia, head trauma), psychiatric (e.g., bipolar, schizophrenia, or depression), or substance dependency (alcohol or chemical dependency) in the past 5 years that are the main contributor to MCI, Contraindications to exercise, e.g. unstable angina, recent surgery, New symptoms or diseases that have not been evaluated by a health care provider, Current enrollment in another intervention study related to cognitive improvement (reduce confounding effects on outcomes), and Abnormal MRI findings.

references.citation: Li D, Mielke MM, Bell WR, Reilly C, Zhang L, Lin FV, Yu F. Blood biomarkers as surrogate endpoints of treatment responses to aerobic exercise and cognitive training (ACT) in amnestic mild cognitive impairment: the blood biomarkers study protocol of a randomized controlled trial (the ACT Trial). Trials. 2020 Jan 6;21(1):19. doi: 10.1186/s13063-019-3798-1.

Yu F, Lin FV, Salisbury DL, Shah KN, Chow L, Vock D, Nelson NW, Porsteinsson AP, Jack C Jr. Efficacy and mechanisms of combined aerobic exercise and cognitive training in mild cognitive impairment: study protocol of the ACT trial. Trials. 2018 Dec 22;19(1):700. doi: 10.1186/s13063-018-3054-0.
